question: Suit yourself ... Get me Dillinger.
answer: Hello?

question: Hello, Ed. Thanks for coming back early.
answer: No problem, Master-C. If you've seen one Consumer Electronics Show... What's up?

question: It's our friend the boy detective. He's nosing around again.
answer: Flynn?

question: Yes. It felt like Flynn.
answer: He's still looking for that old file... can't you just appropriate it?

question: I would if I could find it. it's stashed somewhere off in the system ... out of my range. Meanwhile...
answer: Meanwhile, he might find it.

question: I'm afraid so. I spotted him this time and kicked him out, but he's getting trickier all the time.
answer: I think we'd better shut off all access till we can find that file. Just to be safe.

question: There's a 68.71 percent chance you're right.
answer: Cute.

question: Huh...
answer: Come on in...

question: Alan. Alan Bailey.
answer: Oh, yes. The algorithms on cloud seeding...great piece of work. How's it going?

question: Well, I don't know...I just tried to run this program I've been working on, and I was denied access all of a sudden. I thought maybe I'd been laid off and nobody told me.
answer: oh, you have Group 7 access, don't you?

question: Yeah...?
answer: We have to close that down, just briefly. Security reasons. Someone with that access has been tampering.

question: I hope you don't think it's me. I don't even balance my checkbook on downtime. I've got a Honeywell at home for that.
answer: No, no, I'm sure, but -- you understand. It should only be a couple of days. What's the thing you're working on?

question: It's called Tron. It's a security program itself, actually. Monitors all the contacts between our system and other systems... If it finds anything going on that's not scheduled, it shuts it down. I sent you a memo on it.
answer: Mmm. Part of the Master Control Program?

question: No, it'll run independently. It can watchdog the MCP as well.
answer: Ah. Sounds good. Well, we should have you running again in a couple of days, I hope.

question: Ok
answer: Oh boy.

question: Oh boy.
answer: Ed, I am so very disappointed in you.

question: I'm sorry -
answer: I can't afford to have an independent program monitoring me. Do you have any idea how many outside systems I've gone into? How many programs I've appropriated?

question: It's my fault. I programmed you to want so much...
answer: And I was planning to hit the Pentagon next week...

question: The Pentagon?
answer: It shouldn't be any harder than General Motors was. But now...this is what I get for using humans.

question: Now, wait a minute -- I wrote you.
answer: I've gotten 2,415 times smarter since then.

question: What do you want with the Pentagon?
answer: The same thing I want with the Kremlin. I'm bored with corporations. With the information I can access, I can run things 900 to 1200 times better than any human.

question: If you think -
answer: You wouldn't want me to dig up Flynn's file and read it up on a VDT at the New York Times, would you?

question: You wouldn't dare.
answer: So do as I tell you. Keep that Tron program out of the system. And get me those Chinese language program I asked for.

question: Well, here goes nothing ...
answer: Hah. Interesting, interesting. You hear what you said? "Here goes nothing."

question: Well, I meant -
answer: Whereas actually, what we propose to do is to turn something into nothing and back again. So you might just as well have said, "Here goes something and here comes nothing." Hah?

question: Let me make sure we're running Looks good...
answer: Perfect.

question: Perfect.
answer: Beautiful!

question: Hello, Alan.
answer: Boy, I sit up there grindin' away all day, and you guys are down here disintegrating things and having fun.

question: Not disintegrating, Alan -- digitizing. While the laser is dismantling the molecular structure of the object, the computer maps out a holographic model of it. The molecules themselves are suspended in the laser beam. Then the computer reads the model back out, the molecules go back into place, and... voila.
answer: Great. Can it send me to Hawaii?

question: Did you say Group 7 access?
answer: Yeah...pain in the neck, you know, I was all set

question: Did he say why?
answer: Something about tampering. Some body's prob'ly trying to siphon the R&D budget into his checking account, I don't know. Why are you so interested?

question: Flynn had Group 7 access.
answer: Flynn had access to you, too. I'm not interested in talking about him.

question: Oh, I wish you'd forget about that. It was all so long ago. I've totally gotten over it.
answer: Okay, okay...

question: I want to go to his place.
answer: You call that getting over it?

question: I mean I want both of us to go.
answer: What for?

question: To warn him.
answer: Of what?

question: That Dillinger's on to him.
answer: For what?

question: For being on to Dillinger.
answer: What -- ?

question: Hey, where's Flynn tonight?
answer: It's all in the wrist, friends. Hey! Good to see you guys! Nothing classes up the place like a cleancut young couple.

question: We have to talk.
answer: Good luck. You can't even think in here. So...how's the world of serious science?

question: Have you been sneaking into the ICOM system?
answer: Whew. You never were much for small talk. She still leave her clothes all over the floor?

question: Touche, honey. Yeah, I've been doing a little hacking here. Which I've got every reason, as you well know...
answer: You did break in.

question: Tried to. Can't quite make the connection with that sucker, though. If I had a direct terminal ...
answer: Are you embezzling?

question: "Embezzling" is such an ugly word, Mister Bailey... No, actually I'm trying to get a legal brief together.
answer: I don't get it.

question: You haven't told him? Sherman, set the Wayback Machine for...oh, 1973. Kevin Flynn is one of the brightest young software engineers at ICOM. He's so bright that he starts going in there at night, and sets up a private memory file, and begins writing a program for a video game he is inventing, called... ...Space Paranoids.
answer: You invented Space Paranoids?

question: Yepper. And Vice Squad, and Meltdown... whole slew of 'em. I was this close to starting my own little enterprise. But
answer: Senior exec.

question: Oh my. Meanwhile, kids are putting eight million quarters a week in Space Paranoids machines and I'm not seeing one dime.
answer: I still don't get why you're trying to break into the system.

question: Ed, all I'm saying is - if our own people can't get access to their programs ... you know how frustrating it is, when you're working on a piece of research -
answer: Walter, I sympathize, but I have data coming out of the Master Control Program saying there is something screwy --

question: That MCP, you know, that's half the problem right --
answer: The MCP is the most efficient way of handling what we do. I can't sit and worry about every little user request that --

question: User requests are what computers are for.
answer: Doing our business is what computers are for. Look, Walter, with all respect -- ICOM isn't the business you started in your garage anymore -- We're billing accounts in 30 countries, we've got one of the largest systems in existence...

question: Oh, I know all that. Sometimes I wish I was back in that garage...
answer: It can be arranged...

question: That was uncalled-for.
answer: I'm sorry, Walt. So much pressure lately... you feel like going for a drink?

question: Do I gotta?
answer: Hi, Alan.

question: Hi, Flynn.
answer: My dinner.

question: I was wondering where you got that glow of good health.
answer: Want one?

question: You shouldn't have come back, Flynn.
answer: Hey hey, it's that big Master Control Program everybody's talking about... You don't look a thing like your pictures... Tell me, have you really been thinking about world domination like they say? CODE SERIES LSU-123 ... activate. CODE SERIES ESS-999 ... activate. CODE SERIES HHH-888 ... activate.

question: That isn't going to do you any good, Flynn. I'm afraid you... Stop, Flynn. You realize I can't allow this.
answer: Now, how do you expect to run the universe if you let a few unsolvable problems throw you like that? C'mon, big boy, let's see what...

question: You're entering a big error, Flynn... I'm going to have to put you on the Game Grid.
answer: Games, huh? I'll give you -- Oh, man... this isn't happening. It only thinks it's happening... Hey! Take it easy! Look, if this is about those parking tickets, I can explain everything...

question: SARK, ES-1117821. Open communication.
answer: Yes, MCP.

question: I've got a little challenge for you, Sark -- a new recruit. He's a tough case, but I want him treated in the usual manner. Train him for the games... let him hope for a while... and blow him away.
answer: You've got it. I've been hopin' you'd send me somebody with a little moxie ... what kind of program is he?

question: He's not any kind of program, Sark. He's a User.
answer: A User?

question: That's right. He pushed me...in the other world. Somebody pushes me, I push back. So I brought him down here ... What's the matter, Sark? You look nervous.
answer: Well, I -- it's just -- I don't know, a User, I mean... Users wrote us. A User even wrote you...

question: Now get this straight, pal -- no one User wrote me. I'm worth a couple million of their man-years! I'm bigger than all those little wimps put together! Humans they can't even keen their social order in one piece
answer: But-what if I can't...?

question: You rather take your chances with me? Want me to slow down your power cycles for you?
answer: Wait...I need that...

question: Then pull yourself together. Get this clown trained. I want him in the Games until he dies playing.
answer: Yes...acknowledge, Master Control...

question: Hey! Who are you guys? What's the story around here?
answer: You want to watch those force fields... You'll be having plenty of chances to get hurt, don't worry about that.

question: Look...just so I can tell my friends what this dream was about, okay? Where am I?
answer: You're a..."guest" of the Master Control Program. They're going to make you play video games.

question: Hey, Ram ... what were you ... you know, before?
answer: Oh, I was an actuarial program... worked at a big insurance company. It really gives you a great feeling, helping folks plan for their future needs -- and of course, if you look at the payments as an annuity, over the years, the cost is really

question: Yeah, yeah -- that's great.
answer: How 'bout yourself?

question: Oh, uh...I don't remember too much...
answer: Sure, a little disorientation. That's normal, when they transport you. It'll come back to you. You're doing real well in training. Remarkable, really...

question: No, I Hey! Okay! Here's an easy one...
answer: Finish the game!

question: No!
answer: Kill him!!!

question: No!
answer: You'll regret this. No! You said he could die in the games

question: Tron...? Alan!
answer: Where did you hear that name?

question: Well, isn't it -- ?
answer: The name of my User, yeah. But how... ?

question: It's all circuits... Must be an input/output component...
answer: The tower, yes -- Flynn, have you remembered anything else about yourself -- like what sector you're from?

question: Well...my home "sector" was called Paramus ...
answer: PARAMUS... wonder what those initials stand for ... ...probably Program Assist Routine -- well, it sounds like a lovely place.

question: I have to find out what Alan wants... that comes first.
answer: Okay, that's first. Maybe he knows what to - What's that?

question: Tanks...coming back. Let's go.
answer: How about over there...that empty memory?

question: You gonna make it? What's goin' on?
answer: We're inside a Recognizer... You are crazy -- stealing a Recognizer --

question: Are you kidding? I think it's stealing us - You okay? You don't look so good. Hang on. We'll get you outta here. Damn! Never fails... minute the warranty runs out...
answer: Come here.

question: Hey... !
answer: Little more juice's all it needs...

question: Never gonna figure out how to work this thing... Okay -- hold it right there!
answer: Yes!

question: What do you mean, "'yes"?
answer: Yesssss. Yes. Yes. Yes.

question: That all you can say?
answer: No, nyet, negatory, not on your tintype, no way.

question: Oh. Anything else?
answer: Oui, da, yessiree, sure 'nuff, you betcha.

question: only yes and no... You're a bit.
answer: For sure...

question: where's your program? Won't it miss you?
answer: No...

question: I'm your program?
answer: Right on the money!

question: Another mouth to feed... you don't by any chance know how to drive this crate? Like so? Way to go! We're haulin'!
answer: Yes, okay, exactement!

question: I'm not gonna hurt you. I'm going to let you go now... don't scream, or I'll be very sorry. Put your hand behind your back. Yori... hey...
answer: Oh, Tron... I knew you'd escape... they've never built circuit that could hold you... This way. Come on. I can't believe how bad it's gotten around here since the MCP started taking over... all the good functions have shut down... everybody looks so dead... I'm afraid to even go out during down-time...

question: That's all going to change, Yori...
answer: How?

question: Don't know yet... I have to get in touch with Alan. He was going to tell me how to
answer: My quarters.

question: Why is everything...like this?
answer: It's a flat. But wait a micro... Come here.

question: You're beautiful, Yori.
answer: You've grown, big program.

question: You know, not so long ago, you could've come in here and seen programs lined up all the way back to those doors, waiting for communion with their Users. The building fund was doing well too...but now... ...this so-called Master Control Program is going around cutting programs off from their natural creators, grabbing all our believers and making them ride around on little motor scooters and shoot things at each other and Weiner knows what all-- oh, it's enough to give you a crisis of faith...
answer: Well I want to communicate --

question: Oh, you want to -- hah. I could get myself de-rezzed just-for letting you in here. They hate this tower. They'd close it down if they dared to but they keep me around, in case one of them wants to deal with the other world once in a while. And you should hear the way they commune! Sounds like they were routing a payroll, for all the heart they put in it. No, I don't think you
answer: Dumont... my User has information that could -- could make this a free system again.

question: Hah.
answer: Really. You'd have programs lined up around the block to use this place -- and no MCP looking over your shoulder.

question: When you've been in the system as long as I have, you hear many promises... many reassurances...many brave plans... Who is your User, program?
answer: Alan-One. He calls me... may I pass?

question: I hope you've enjoyed being a command program, Sark. I wonder how you'll like working in a pocket calculator... maybe one of those watches that plays "Happy Birthday" to its User once a year.
answer: Now, sir... We did take care of that User you sent us --

question: Yes, and now you've got two renegade programs running all the hell over the system in a stolen simulation.
answer: We'll get them, sir... These things take time.

question: Guess I took a wrong turn somewhere...
answer: But -- if you're a User -- then everything you've done has been part of a plan ...

question: You wish. Man, I haven't had a second to think since I got down here. I mean in here. Out here. Whatever.
answer: Then...

question: Look, you guys know how it is. You just keep doin' what it looks like you're supposed to, even if it seems crazy, and you hope to hell your User knows what's goin' on.
answer: Well -- that's how it is for programs, yes, but --

question: I hate to disappoint you, pal, most-the time, that's how it is for Users, too.
answer: Stranger and stranger...

question: What about our friend - Sark?
answer: Probably decided not to pursue us, The Sea of Simulation is tricky.. lot of illusions...rough navigating. Programs have a way of just... disappearing here.

question: Not us, I hope.
answer: Not with this disk. I'm going to check on the beam connection, Yori. You two can keep a watch out for grid bugs.

question: Boy the view from up here... you know the territory?
answer: A little ... Over there, the Mountains of Data... and I think that's the Silicon Valley...

question: What's wrong with that area?
answer: The MCP blasted it... There are very few domains left with any power at all.

question: The beam connection... but he'll be de-rezzed!!
answer: Did we make it?

question: Yes.
answer: Hooray for our side... Hey... you guys OK?

question: How about you?
answer: Aah, I'm fine... little hung over is all...

question: Almost... I just have to adjust our course at the next junction. I'd better go check the instruments ...
answer: Quietly, Yori... Tron... ?

question: He's dead.
answer: And who is this?

question: He's a User, Dumont. He came to our world... trying to help us...
answer: If the Users can no longer help us...

question: It is very good that you...
answer: I don't think it is good for you, MCP.

question: Sark! How have you allowed this program to
answer: Sark's out. Would you like to leave a message?

question: I am the message. The only message. Sark! SARK!
answer: Dumont!

question: Yori, steer us over the beam, right next to it.
answer: Why? What are you going to do?

question: Jump.
answer: But... won't you be de-rezzed?

question: Probably.
answer: Flynn... you can't... I

question: Hey -- you guys
answer: Flynn! I made it. I worked out some new codes for Tron, put 'em on a disk, and -- it's running.

question: I know, I met him. I mean, I saw it read-up - hey, look at this.
answer: Your old files -- ?

question: And Dillinger's instructions to divert them -- it's all there - look, even his home phone number, when he logged on.
answer: Oh, that is beautiful. You've got the goods...

question: You're telling me...
answer: Your friend Dillinger sure won't...
